newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Who's who in Hong Kong - Tycoons at a glance.
newsitem.headline: Who's who in Hong Kong - Tycoons at a glance.

text.p: The British colony of Hong Kong reverts to Beijing's sovereignty at midnight on June 30, when it will become a quasi-autonomous capitalist region of communist- ruled China. Here are sketches of tycoons who play a leading role in the territory's economic and political life.

Ronnie CHAN - Chairman of Hang Lung Hang Lung Development Co Ltd and Amoy Properties Ltd Forbes Magazine named the Chan family among the world's 400 richest individuals in both 1995 and 1996. Born in Hong Kong on December 11, 1949, Chan serves on the boards of a number of overseas-listed companies, including Standard Chartered Plc and Enron Corp He is on the World Economic Forum (WEF) council.

CHENG Yu-Tung - Chairman of New World Development Co Ltd Born in China on August 27, 1925. He got his start as an apprentice in a goldsmith's shop before deciding that construction and real estate were more to his liking. In Hong Kong, New World is engaged mainly in property development and investment, but it is also engaged in hotels and restaurants, infrastructure and construction. Other ventures include television broadcasting, telecommunications, department stores and insurance. The group is also engaged in infrastructure and property development in China. Cheng is a member of China's Preparatory Committee responsible for hammering out the details of Hong Kong's reversion to China.

Linus CHEUNG - The first Chinese chief executive of Hong Kong Telecommunications Ltd Born in Hong Kong on May 30, 1948 in a grassroots family. As a child, he had to help his parents with their newspaper distribution business. After he graduated from the University of Hong Kong in 1971, he joined Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd, where he eventually rose to deputy managing director after 24 years of service. He left Cathay to take his current position in March 1994. He was appointed in January 1995 to the board of Britain's Cable & Wireless Plc, Hongkong Telecom's largest shareholder. Cheung is an adviser to the Chinese Society of Macroeconomics of the State Planning Commission of China.

Stanley HO - Chairman of Shun Tak Holdings Ltd which operates one of the world's biggest fleets of high-speed ferries with a mix of jetfoils and foilcats. Macau casino tycoon. Born in Hong Kong on November 25, 1921 of Chinese and British descent. Managing director of Sociedade de Turismo e Diversoes de Macau, which operates nine casinos, hotels and entertainment facilities, real estate and infrastructural projects in Portuguese-ruled Macau. He is vice president of Macau Airport Co which runs Macau's airport. He took part in the drafting of Macau's future constitution.

Michael KADOORIE - Chairman of power operator China Light & Power Co Ltd and hotel operator Hongkong and Shanghai Hotels Ltd Born in Hong Kong on July 19, 1941. His Jewish family, which emigrated to Hong Kong from Baghdad in 1880, always makes the Fortune magazine list of the 100 richest people worldwide. Kadoorie inherited the business when his father died in 1993.

Robert KUOK - A billionaire Malaysian of Chinese descent, born in Johor Bahru in 1923. He controls hotel chain Shangri-La Asia Ltd, newspaper publisher South China Morning Post (Holdings) Ltd, Kuala Lumpur-listed giants Perlis Plantations Bhd and Federal Flour Mills Bhd His Kerry Holdings Ltd also holds a substantial interest in Television Broadcasts Ltd Kuok built his fortune on sugar, earning the nickname the Sugar King. He started trading for sugar plantations, and was soon growing, refining and shipping it. He is a member of China's Preparatory Committee responsible for hammering out details of Hong Kong's handover.

Walter KWOK - Chairman of Sun Hung Kai Properties Ltd Born in Macau on October 25, 1950. Eldest son of late Kwok Tak-seng, one of the trio who founded the Sun Hung Kai Group. He was natural heir to the empire when his father died in 1990. He has a master of science degree from University of London's Imperial College. He is a member of China's Preparatory Committee responsible for hammering out the details of Hong Kong's reversion to China, an adviser to Beijing on Hong Kong affairs, and a member of the national committee of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference.

LEE Hon Chiu - Chairman of Hysan Development Co Ltd Born in Hong Kong on February 21, 1929 as the grandson of the company's founder. Lee, disproving the axiom that the third generation squanders the wealth, has turned the company into an expanding group with extensive property investments. Trained as an engineer, he studied in the United States at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Stanford University. Lee is a director of the Securities and Futures Commission, the local securities watchdog.

Sir Quo-Wei LEE - Chairman of Hang Seng Bank Ltd Born in Macau on August 5, 1918. He joined Hang Seng Bank in the mid-1940s, working up through the ranks from accountant and sub-manager to the chairmanship he has held since 1988. He is an adviser to the board of HSBC Holdings Plc. He is an adviser to Beijing on Hong Kong.

LEE Shau-Kee - Chairman of property developer Henderson Land Development Co Ltd and gas operator Hong Kong and China Gas Co Ltd Born in China on January 29, 1929. Forbes Magazine in February named him as Asia's fourth-richest man. He is a member of China's Preparatory Committee responsible for hammering out the details of Hong Kong's reversion to China, and an adviser to Beijing on Hong Kong affairs. In 1949 he came to Hong Kong with his first jobs at goldsmiths and money changers. Later he ran an import-export business, before going into real estate in 1965. He founded Henderson Land in 1976.

David LI - Chairman of Bank of East Asia Ltd Born in London on March 13, 1939 to a wealthy Hong Kong Family. He studied economics and law at Cambridge University. He is a member of China's Preparatory Committee responsible for hammering out the details of Hong Kong's reversion to China, and an adviser to Beijing on Hong Kong affairs.

LI Ka-Shing - Chairman of property developer Cheung Kong (Holdings) Ltd and conglomerate Hutchison Whampoa Ltd Born in China on June 13, 1928. Forbes magazine named him as one of the world's 10 richest individuals in 1995. He is a member of China's Preparatory Committee responsible for hammering out the details of Hong Kong's reversion to China, an adviser to Beijing on Hong Kong affairs, and a former member of a committee that drafted Hong Kong's post-colonial constitution.

Alasdair MORRISON - Managing director of Jardine Matheson Holdings Ltd, whose history in the region dates back to its involvement in the opium trade in 1830s China. Born in Edinburgh on September 29, 1948, Morrison was educated at Eton College before attending Cambridge University and studied briefly at Harvard Business School. His directorships include Mandarin Oriental International Ltd, Hongkong Land Holdings Ltd, and Dairy Farm International Holdings Ltd

Robert NG - Chairman of Sino Land Co Ltd Son of Singapore property magnate Ng Teng Fong. During the stock market crash of 1987, Sino Land suffered losses in the futures market and was left bargaining with the government over a repayment schedule for the debts. But Ng was still able to build up his land bank in the following years, and Hong Kong's galloping market in the early 1990s put the company back in the black.

Sir William PURVES - Chairman of banking group HSBC Holdings Plc Born in Scotland on December 27, 1931. British. He joined HSBC's Hong Kong unit, the Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corp, in 1954 before being named chairman in December 1986. With the establishment of HSBC Holdings in 1991, he assumed the chairmanship of both the holding company and the bank. In January 1993, he retired as bank chairman but remains HSBC's group chairman. He was made a Commander of the Order of the British Empire in June 1988, and was knighted in 1993 in the Queen's New Years Honours list.

Sir Run Run SHAW - Chairman of Television Broadcasts Ltd and its controlling shareholder Shaw Brothers (Hong Kong) Ltd Son of a Shanghai magnate. Born in Shanghai on October 14, 1907, Shaw and his brother got their start in the 1920s by producing a play in their family's theatre. They made China's first film. Shaw has long been active in community service, for which he has been knighted. He is a member of China's Preparatory Committee responsible for hammering out the details of Hong Kong's reversion to China,

Peter SUTCH - Chairman of Swire Pacific Ltd and Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd Born in Hitchin, Britain on April 8, 1945. British. He joined John Swire & Sons in 1966 in the shipping division. He was transferred to Hong Kong's flag carrier, Cathay Pacific, in 1970 and worked for 11 years in its various divisions in Japan and Hong Kong. He became managing director in 1984 and rose in 1992 to chairman of Swire Group in Hong Kong.

Peter WOO - Former chairman of Wharf Holdings Ltd and Wheelock & Co Ltd Born in Shanghai on Septeber 5, 1946. He worked at Chase Manhattan Bank in New York for three years before joining the companies of his late father-in-law, shipping tycoon Sir Yue-kong Pao -- Wharf and Wheelock. Woo took over as chairman of the two in 1986. But he resigned from Wharf and Wheelock in 1993 and 1995 to concentrate on public service, although he remained honorary chairman of the two firms until announcing a bid for leadership of the territory last year. He is a member of China's Preparatory Committee responsible for hammering out the details of Hong Kong's reversion to China. He is chairman of Hong Kong's Hospital Authority.

Gordon WU - Chairman of infrastructure developer Hopewell Holdings Ltd Born in Hong Kong on December 3, 1935, he began his business in 1969 after persuading his father, a former taxi driver and self-made millionaire, to guarantee a loan for him. One of his strengths is his engineering acumen, which he began developing during his years as a civil engineering student at Princeton University. Pressed for cash, in October 1996, he agreed to sell a controlling interest in Hopewell unit Consolidated Electric Power Asia Ltd, but remained the company's chairman.

Larry YUNG - Chairman of CITIC Pacific Ltd, a subsidiary of China's investment flagship, China International Trust and Investment Corp. Born in Shanghai on January 18, 1942, into a prosperous textile and flour family business. His father, Rong Yiren, is vice president of China. The "red princeling's" 1965 university graduation from electrical engineering studies in China butted up against the Cultural Revolution, during which he was sent to work at power stations in rural China. He returned to Beijing in 1972 and did research at a state laboratory. In 1978 he came to Hong Kong to develop his family's businesss and to invest in venture-capital projects in the U.S. He became vice chairman and managing director of China Internatonal Trust & Investment Corp Hong Kong (Holdings) Ltd when it was set up in 1987. In 1990, CITIC HK took over listed company Tylfull Co Ltd, and renamed it CITIC Pacific Ltd. Larry Yung is a steward of the Hong Kong Jockey Club.
